revision.text:
{{redirect|HMCS Protecteur|the former RCN naval base|HMCS Protector}} {{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:HMCS Protecteur (AOR 509).jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=HMCS ''Protecteur'' in [[Pearl Harbor, Hawaii|Pearl Harbor]] after a port visit in 2009 }} {{Infobox ship career |Ship country=Canada |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Canada|naval}} |Ship service=[[Royal Canadian Navy]] |Ship name=''Protecteur'' |Ship ordered=16 December 1966 |Ship builder=[[Saint John Shipbuilding]] |Ship laid down=17 October 1967 |Ship launched=18 July 1968 |Ship commissioned=30 August 1969 |Ship decommissioned=14 May 2015 |Ship homeport= [[CFB Esquimalt]], British Columbia |Ship motto=*''Soutien avec Courage'' ("Support with Courage") |Ship honours= *[[Gulf and Kuwait Medal|Gulf and Kuwait]] *Arabian Sea |Ship fate=Sold for [[Ship breaking|scrapping]] 27 November 2015<ref name=dedyna1/> at [[Liverpool, Nova Scotia]]<ref name=ward1>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/hmcs-protecteur-liverpool-1.3466327 |title=Former HMCS Protecteur towed from Esquimalt, will bring jobs to Liverpool |last=Ward |first=Rachel |work=CBC News |date=26 February 2016 |accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref> |Ship badge=Azure, a silver helmet with the five grills or, garnished of the last, and bearing a coronet "fleur-de-lis" also or.<ref>{{cite book |last=Arbuckle |first=J. Graeme |date=1987 |title=Badges of the Canadian Navy |publisher=Nimbus Publishing |location=Halifax, Nova Scotia |isbn=0-920852-49-1 |pages=94}}</ref> }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Ship class={{sclass-|Protecteur|replenishment oiler}} |Ship displacement=*{{convert|8380|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} standard *{{convert|24700|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} full load |Ship length={{convert|171.9|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|23.2|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|10.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=*2 × [[Babcock & Wilcox]] [[boiler]]s *1 × [[General Electric]] [[steam turbine]] *{{convert|21000|shp|kW|lk=in|abbr=on}} |Ship speed={{convert|20|kn|lk=in}} |Ship range=*{{convert|7500|nmi|abbr=on|lk=in}} *at {{convert|11.5|kn}} |Ship complement=365 officers and crew (men and women) including 45 in air detachment |Ship EW=*4 × [[BAE Systems]] [[Mark 36 SRBOC]] [[Chaff (countermeasure)|chaff launchers]] *[[AN/SLQ-25 Nixie]] towed decoy |Ship armament=*2 × 20 mm [[Phalanx CIWS|Phalanx]] [[Close-in weapon system|CIWS]] *6 × [[.50 calibre machine gun]]s |Ship aircraft=3 × CH-124 Sea King helicopters |Ship ice class=3 }} |} '''Her Majesty's Canadian Ship (HMCS) ''Protecteur'' (AOR 509)''' was the lead ship of the {{sclass-|Protecteur|replenishment oiler}}s in service with the [[Royal Canadian Navy]]. She was part of the [[Maritime Forces Pacific]] (MARPAC), [[home port|homeported]] at [[CFB Esquimalt]], British Columbia. Built by [[Saint John Shipbuilding]] and Dry Docks in [[Saint John, New Brunswick]], she was commissioned on 30 August 1969. She was the first Canadian naval unit to carry the name ''Protecteur''; however, there have been several units, including a base, named {{HMCS|Protector}}.
Mostly known for her humanitarian efforts, ''Protecteur'' had also served in times of war including [[Operation Friction]] and [[Operation Apollo]] in the Persian Gulf region, multi-national naval exercises and as part of the [[International Force for East Timor|INTERFET]] in [[East Timor]]. Operation Apollo was the largest deployment of the Royal Canadian Navy since the [[Canada in the Korean War|Korean War]]. In six months ''Protecteur'' logged over {{convert|50000|nmi}}, delivering over {{bbl to t|150000}} of fuel and 390 pallets of dry goods to deployed coalition ships. ''Protecteur'', as well as her [[sister ship]] ''Preserver'', were scheduled to be [[paid off]] in 2017, however damage due to an engine fire aboard the ship in 2014 forced ''Protecteur'' to be prematurely [[Ship commissioning#Ship decommissioning|paid off]]. ''Protecteur'' was decommissioned at a farewell ceremony on 14 May 2015.<ref name=CTV-2015-05-14>{{cite news |url= http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/farewell-ceremony-for-hmcs-protecteur-after-46-years-at-sea-1.2375128 |title= Farewell ceremony for HMCS Protecteur after 46 years at sea |date= 14 May 2015 |author= Dirk Meissner |agency= The Canadian Press |work= CTV News }}</ref>
==Building ''Protecteur''== ''Protecteur'' was the first Canadian naval unit to carry the name ''Protecteur''; however, there have been two [[HMAS Protector|Australian]] and seven [[HMS Protector|British]] naval units named ''Protector''. The name was also used for a Canadian base, named {{HMCS|Protector}}.<ref name="commissioning book" />
===Construction=== First authorized in 1959,<ref>{{cite journal |title=Milestones in Canadian Naval History |journal=Canadian Naval Review |url=http://www.navalreview.ca/wp-content/uploads/public/vol6num1/vol6num1art7.pdf |format=PDF |volume= 6 |issue=Num. 1 (Spring 2010) |year=2010 |page=31 |access-date=30 April 2014}}</ref> HMCS ''Protecteur'' was constructed by [[Saint John Shipbuilding]] and Dry Docks in [[Saint John, New Brunswick]] starting on 17 October 1967,<ref name="Wertheim2007">{{cite book |last=Wertheim |first=Eric |title=The Naval Institute Guide to Combat Fleets of the World: Their Ships, Aircraft, and Systems |url={{google books|TJunjRvplU4C|page=82|plainurl=yes}} |edition=1st |year=2007 |publisher=Naval Institute Press |isbn=978-1-59114-955-2 |page=82}}</ref><ref name="Tracy2012">{{cite book |last=Tracy |first=Nicholas |title=Two-Edged Sword: The Navy as an Instrument of Canadian Foreign Policy |url={{google books|eLQKvMpsc9gC|page=11|plainurl=yes}} |accessdate=2 December 2013 |date=2 October 2012 |publisher=[[McGill-Queen's University Press]] |isbn=978-0-7735-8781-6 |page=149}}</ref> was launched on 18 July 1968,<ref name="Wertheim2007" /> and was officially commissioned by the [[Royal Canadian Navy]] on 30 August 1969.<ref name="insignia and lineages">{{cite book |title=The Insignia and Lineages of the Canadian Forces |url=http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/his/ol-lo/vol-tom-2/par1/doc/ecs-ns.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=29 November 2013 |volume=Volume 2 , Part 1 |date=8 January 2001 |publisher=Canadian Forces Heritage Publication |pages=2–81–2–82}}</ref>
===General characteristics=== ''Protecteur'' was one of two ships in the ''Protecteur''-class of replenishment oilers in service with the Royal Canadian Navy. The ship is {{convert|171.9|m|ftin|}} long and {{convert|23.2|m|ftin}} wide, with a [[displacement (ship)|displacement]] between {{convert|8380|and|24700|t|LT|0|abbr=off}} depending on her load.<ref name="ships stats">{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.forces.gc.ca/protecteur/1/1-s_eng.asp?category=17&title=578 |title=Ship's Characteristics |date=2 June 2013 |accessdate=29 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607202504/http://www.navy.forces.gc.ca/protecteur/1/1-s_eng.asp?category=17&title=578 |archivedate=7 June 2013}}</ref> ''Protecteur'''s [[draught (hull)|draught]] is {{convert|10.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}},<ref name="ships stats" /> and she had been given an [[ice rating]] of three.<ref name="ice class">{{cite journal |last=<!-- Staff --> |year=1983 |title=HMCS ''Protecteur'' |journal=Marine News |publisher=[[World Ship Society]] |location=Kendal, England |volume=37 |page=423 |issn=0025-3243 |oclc=8782985 |url={{google books|kmBUAAAAMAAJ|page=423|plainurl=yes}} |accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref>
Two [[Babcock & Wilcox]] [[boiler]]s feed a single [[General Electric]] [[steam turbine]] rated at {{convert|21000|shp|kW|lk=in}} that drives a single propeller,<ref name="Wertheim2007"/> allowing the ship to reach a maximum speed of {{convert|20|kn|lk=in}}.<ref name="ships stats" /> At {{convert|20|kn}}, the range of ''Protecteur'' was limited to {{convert|4100|nmi|abbr=off|lk=in}}, but her range could be extended to {{convert|7500|nmi}} when only traveling at {{convert|11.5|kn}}.<ref name="ships stats" />
''Protecteur'''s primary role was to deliver supplies to deployed ships. Fully loaded, ''Protecteur'' could store up to {{convert|14590|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} of fuel, {{convert|400|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} of [[aviation fuel]], {{convert|1048|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} of dry cargo, and {{convert|1250|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} of ammunition.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2013/09/03/canadas-pacific-fleet-cant-catch-a-break/ |title=Canada's Pacific fleet can't catch a break |last=Taylor-Vaisey |first=Nick |date=3 September 2013 |work=[[Maclean's]] |publisher=Rogers Media |accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref> Fuel could be transferred at a rate of {{convert|1500|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} per hour and {{convert|2500|lbs|kg|abbr=on}} of dry cargo per hour could be transferred all while traveling at her top speed.<ref name="commissioning book">{{cite book |title=The Commissioning of HMCS Protecteur |url=http://www.forposterityssake.ca/Navy/HMCS_PROTECTUER_509_SUB1.htm |accessdate=9 December 2013 |date=30 August 1969 |publisher=[[Saint John Shipbuilding]] and Dry Dock Company |location=[[Saint John, NB]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213014659/http://www.forposterityssake.ca/Navy/HMCS_PROTECTUER_509_SUB1.htm|archivedate=13 December 2013}}</ref> [[File:HMCS Regina and Protecteur - RAS 2013.jpg|thumb|left|HMCS ''Regina'' being [[underway replenishment|refueled]] by ''Protecteur'' in the Pacific Ocean.]]
===Armament=== Four [[BAE Systems]] [[Mark 36 SRBOC]] [[Chaff (countermeasure)|chaff launchers]] and an [[AN/SLQ-25 Nixie]] towed decoy were the ship's primary defenses.<ref name="ships stats" /> When ''Protecteur'' was originally launched, she was fitted with a twin [[3"/50 caliber gun]] mounted on her bow,<ref name="commissioning book" /> however the 3" guns were replaced with two 20 mm [[Phalanx CIWS|Phalanx]] [[close-in weapon system|CIWS]] mounts, one at the bow and one astern in August 1990. The CIWS emplacements were part of the upgrades that ''Protecteur'' received before deploying to the Persian Gulf region.<ref name="Janes">{{cite journal |title=Jane's Defence Weekly |url={{google books|vK1DAQAAIAAJ|plainurl=yes}} |volume= 17 |year=1992 |publisher=[[Jane's Information Group|Jane's Publishing]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/436248793?accountid=3357 |title=Canadian vessels bulk up for gulf |last=Spears |first=John |date=18 August 1990 |work=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=[[Star Media Group]] |page=A12 |accessdate=30 November 2013 |subscription=yes |via=[[ProQuest]]}}</ref>
Her former 3"/50 guns were temporarily fitted,<ref name="76mmgun">{{cite news |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/243502307?accountid=3357 |date=25 August 1990 |work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|publisher=[[Postmedia Network]] |page=B8 |accessdate=30 November 2013 |agency=[[The Canadian Press]] |subscription=yes |via=ProQuest |title=Canadians 'chugging along,' navy says}}</ref> together with two [[Bofors 40 mm gun]]s, six {{convert|0.5|in|mm|1|adj=on}} machine guns, as well as [[Blowpipe (missile)|Blowpipe]] and [[Javelin (surface-to-air missile)|Javelin]] [[MANPAD]]s during the Gulf War.<ref>{{cite book |last=Baker |first=A.D. |title=The Naval Institute Guide to Combat Fleets of the World 1998–1999: Their Ships, Aircraft, and Systems |year=1998 |publisher=Naval Institute Press |location=Annapolis, Maryland |isbn=1-55750-111-4 |pages=83–84}}</ref> The CIWS mounts were retained after the war,<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Saunders |editor1-first=Stephen |title=Jane's Fighting Ships |edition=2002–2003 |publisher=Jane's Information Group |isbn=0710624328 |page=65 |location=Coulsdon, UK}}</ref> but the Bofors and 76 mm gun were removed from ''Protecteur'' after returning from war.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Saunders |editor1-first=Stephen|title=Jane's Fighting Ships|edition=2004–2005|publisher=Jane's Information Group|isbn=0-7106-2623-1|page=186|location=Coulsdon, UK}}</ref>
Originally ''Protecteur'' was to be fitted with [[RIM-7 Sea Sparrow|Mark 29 NATO Sea Sparrow]]. However, due to delays in procurement, the Sea Sparrow system was never installed.<ref>{{cite journal|date=17 October 2009|title=SeaWaves Today in History|publisher=Shirlaw News Group|oclc=77076813|issn=1710-6966|url=http://www.seawaves.com/TDIH/october/17Oct.txt|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> The [[Sikorsky CH-124 Sea King]] helicopters on board ''Protecteur'' also provided weapons support, carrying [[Mark 46 torpedo]]es and a [[7.62×51mm NATO|7.62 mm]] machine gun.<ref name="Crawford2003">{{cite book |last=Crawford |first=Steve |title=Twenty-first Century Military Helicopters: Today's Fighting Gunships |url={{google books|bd5hQiT2JRgC|page=9|plainurl=yes}} |accessdate=9 December 2013 |year=2003 |publisher=[[Zenith Imprint]] |isbn=978-0-7603-1504-0 |page=9}}</ref>
===Crew=== Three hundred sixty five men and women served on ''Protecteur''. There were 27 officers aboard ship and a total of 45 crew members who were part of the air detachment that flew three CH-124 Sea King helicopters off the back of the ship.<ref name="ships stats" /><ref name="Maritime Engineering">{{cite journal |title=Canadian Shipping and Marine Engineering |url={{google books|a6UfAAAAMAAJ|page=223|plainurl=yes}} |volume= 43 |year=1971 |publisher=[[Maclean-Hunter]] |page=223}}</ref> In 1988 the crew of the ''Protecteur'' was officially [[Sex segregation#Mandatory sex segregation|desegregated]], allowing both men and women to serve on board her.<ref name="MorinGimblett1997">{{cite book |last1=Morin |first1=Jean H., Maj. |last2=Gimblett |first2=Richard H., LCdr. |title=Operation Friction 1990–1991: The Canadian Forces in the Persian Gulf |url={{google books|4drL0pEFUDYC|page=275|plainurl=yes}} |accessdate=1 December 2013 |date=7 April 1997 |publisher=[[Dundurn Press]] |isbn=978-1-55488-256-4 |pages=44–47}}</ref> ''Protecteur'' was equipped with a small dental clinic, which provided dental care for the Royal Canadian Navy when deployed.<ref name="Singh2005">{{cite book |last1=Singh |first1=Paramjit |last2=Arora |first2=Vimal |title=Military Dentistary: Terrain, Trends and Training|url={{google books|QJV9faMuBPoC|page=34|plainurl=yes}} |accessdate=1 December 2013 |edition=1st |date=30 December 2005 |publisher=Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers |isbn=978-81-8061-418-7 |page=34}}</ref>
==Service== [[File:HMCS Protecteur during Operation Friction.jpg|thumb|right|''Protecteur'' during Operation Friction]] The Polish yacht ''Gedania'' left [[Resolute Bay]] and went missing on 30 August 1975.<ref name="Gedania1">{{cite news |title=Persuit of Polish Yacht may cost $400,000 |last=<!-- Staff --> |date=12 September 1975 |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |page=8}}</ref> ''Gedania'' was a sailboat, and was only the second pleasure craft to attempt to traverse the [[Northwest Passage]]; however they were turned back due to regulations regarding the passage. The sailboat was on a journey to circumnavigate the North and South American continents.<ref name="yacht 2">{{cite news |title=Editorials |last=Tobolewski |first=Jerzy |date=16 June 1979 |work=Toronto Star |publisher=Torstar Corporation |page=J10a}}</ref> The crew of ''Protecteur'' initiated a $400 thousand (equivalent to ${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|400000|1975|r=-2}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}}){{Inflation-fn|CA}} search for the lost ship before it completed its journey.<ref name="Gedania1" />
In 1980, while ''Protecteur'' was operating off the coast of [[Portugal]], Commanding Officer [[Captain (Canadian naval rank)|Captain]] Larry Dzioba hoisted an [[Esso]] flag on the ship's mast, joking that they were the "biggest floating gas station in the neighbourhood".<ref>{{cite news |title=Canada's Proud Navy Papers Over its Cracks |last=Ward |first=Peter |date=8 June 1980 |work=Toronto Star |page=C19}}</ref> In 1981, ''Protecteur'' served in CARIBOPS 81 off the coast of Puerto Rico, along with at least two Canadian destroyers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ink.ourontario.ca/lp/reel81/00116-x0-y0-z1-r0-0-0?query=protecteur&p=1 |title=Fill'er up |date=27 January 1982 |work=The Leamington Post |location=Leamington, Ontario |publisher=Canadian Newspapers Company |accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref> ''Protecteur'' and her CH-124 helicopters performed a nighttime rescue of the crew of a disabled Norwegian chemical tanker in June 1982. The Norwegian crew was forced to abandon their ship after a fire had broken out.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/bittersweet-50th-anniversary-for-canada-s-sea-king-helicopters-1.1349878 |title=Bittersweet 50th anniversary for Canada's Sea King helicopters |date=31 July 2013 |work=CBC News |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |access-date=12 December 2013}}</ref> For the 75th anniversary of the Royal Canadian Navy, ''Protecteur'' hosted a dinner with the captains of 35 ships, including ships from Belgium, Brazil, Denmark, France, Great Britain, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, and the United States, as well as then Governor General [[Jeanne Sauvé]] and [[Prince Andrew]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Selective coverage |last=Fulton |first=J.A. |date=8 August 1985 |work=The Globe and Mail |page=7}}</ref>
In 1991, ''Protecteur'' was part of the Canadian contingent sent to the Persian Gulf as part of [[Operation Desert Shield (Gulf War)|Operation Desert Shield]] and later [[Operation Friction]] (the Canadian name for its operations during the Gulf War). The ship, part of a three-vessel force,<ref name="three ships in gulf">{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/275215221.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+10%2C+1991&author=Toth%2C+Derrick&pub=Kitchener+-+Waterloo+Record&edition=&startpage=&desc=Protecteur+crew+returns+from+Gulf|title=''Protecteur'' crew returns from Gulf |last=Toth |first=Derrick |date=10 January 1991 |work=[[Waterloo Region Record|Kitchener – Waterloo Record]] |publisher=[[Metroland Media Group]] |page=A1|accessdate=29 November 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203053245/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/275215221.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+10%2C+1991&author=Toth%2C+Derrick&pub=Kitchener+-+Waterloo+Record&edition=&startpage=&desc=Protecteur+crew+returns+from+Gulf|archivedate=3 December 2013|subscription=yes|via=ProQuest}}</ref> the other two being the {{sclass-|Iroquois|destroyer|1}} {{HMCS|Athabaskan|DDG 282|2}} and the {{sclass-|Restigouche|destroyer|1}} {{HMCS|Terra Nova|DDE 259|2}},<ref name="othertwo gulf">{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/436247410.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+23%2C+1990&author=John+Spears+Toronto+Star&pub=Toronto+Star&edition=&startpage=&desc=Canadian+warships+set+to+sail+for+gulf |title=Canadian warships set to sail for gulf |last=Spears |first=John |date=23 August 1990 |work=Toronto Star |publisher=Star Media Group |accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref> saw extensive service in the Central Gulf. The ship was honoured with the [[Gulf and Kuwait Medal]] and the Arabian Sea award for her service in the war.<ref name="McCreery2005">{{cite book |last=McCreery |first=Christopher |title=The Canadian Honours System |url={{google books|HM5lR-0-Kp4C|page=551|plainurl=yes}} |accessdate=1 December 2013 |date=30 April 2005 |publisher=Dundurn Press |isbn=978-1-55488-017-1 |pages=551–553}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |author=Office of the Prime Minister of Canada |author-link=Prime Minister of Canada |url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/news/2014/05/09/south-west-asia-theatre-honours |title=South-West Asia Theatre Honours |publisher=[[Government of Canada]] |location=Ottawa, Ontario |date=9 May 2014 |access-date=9 May 2014}}</ref> In 1992, ''Protecteur'' was sent to help after [[Hurricane Andrew]] in Florida,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/247475/CANADIANS-HELP-REBUILD-2-SCHOOLS-IN-S-FLORIDA.html?pg=all |title=Canadians Help Rebuild 2 Schools in S. Florida |date=15 September 1992 |work=[[Deseret News]] |accessdate=29 November 2013 |agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> with tasks including repairing schools, community centres, and hospitals in the region.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/436701588.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+8%2C+1992&author=CP&pub=Toronto+Star&edition=&startpage=&desc=Canada+sending+hurricane+relief+crews+to+Florida |title=Canada sending hurricane relief crews to Florida |date=8 September 1992 |publisher=Star Media Group |work=Toronto Star |accessdate=29 November 2013 |agency=[[The Canadian Press]]}}</ref> A small pool was built on the helipad of ''Protecteur'' providing some relief to hurricane ravaged Floridians.<ref name="pool" /> Homes, churches, and a senior centre were also repaired in the Bahamas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/275259488.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+26%2C+1992&author=&pub=Kitchener+-+Waterloo+Record&edition=&startpage=&desc=Canadian+sailors+keeping+busy+rebuilding+storm-struck+Bahamas |title=Canadian sailors keeping busy rebuilding storm-struck Bahamas |date=26 October 1992 |work=Kitchener – Waterloo Record|publisher=Metroland Media Group|page=A7|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref> The homeport of ''Protecteur'' was changed from [[CFB Halifax]] to [[CFB Esquimalt]] after the hurricane relief efforts.<ref name="pool">{{cite news|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/239715306?accountid=3357|title=Sailors built pool on ship during mission to aid hurricane victims|date=4 October 1992|work=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|publisher=Postmedia Network|page=A6|accessdate=30 November 2013|subscription=yes|via=ProQuest|agency=The Canadian Press}}</ref> The frigate {{HMCS|Vancouver|FFH 331|2}} and ''Protecteur'' participated in the multi-national [[Exercise RIMPAC|RIMPAC]] 98 off the coast of Hawaii in June 1998.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/275545384.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+6%2C+1998&author=&pub=The+Record&edition=&startpage=&desc=Navy+ships+ready+for+Asian+tour|title=Navy ships ready for Asian tour|date=6 May 1998|work=The Record|publisher=Metroland Media Group|page=A3|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref>
''Protecteur'' was deployed to [[East Timor]] as part of the Australian-led [[International Force for East Timor|INTERFET]] peacekeeping taskforce from 23 October 1999 to 23 January 2000.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Stevens |first=David |title=Strength Through Diversity: The combined naval role in Operation Stabilise |series=Working Papers |volume=20 |year=2007 |publisher=Sea Power Centre – Australia |location=Canberra |isbn=978-0-642-29676-4 |issn=1834-7231 |url=http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Working_Paper_20.pdf |accessdate=6 September 2010 |pages=14–15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312180452/http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Working_Paper_20.pdf |format=PDF |archivedate=12 March 2011 }}</ref> Crew from ''Protecteur'' helped reconstruct a police academy in [[Dili]] during their deployment in support of INTERFET. The [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] then used the newly reconstructed academy to set up a training school for the [[National Police of East Timor]].<ref name="INTERFET">{{cite journal |last=Grunau |first=Steve |year=2003 |title=The Limits of Human Security: Canada in East Timor |journal=Journal of Military and Strategic Studies |publisher=[[Columbia University Press]] |location=New York |volume=6 |issue=1 |oclc=192026323 |url=http://jmss.org/jmss/index.php/jmss/article/viewArticle/237 }}</ref> ''Protecteur'' participated in [[Operation Apollo]] for six months, logging over {{convert|50000|nmi}} and delivering over {{bbl to t|150000}} of fuel and 390 pallets of dry goods,<ref>{{cite journal|date=24 November 2010|title=SeaWaves Today in History|oclc=77076813|publisher=Shirlaw News Group|issn=1710-6966|url=http://www.seawaves.com/TDIH/november/24nov.txt|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> returning to CFB Esquimalt in November 2002.<ref name="opAPOLLO">{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/355735173.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov%2025,%202002&author=&pub=The%20Guelph%20Mercury&edition=&startpage=&desc=HMCS%20Protecteur%20arrives%20home|title=HMCS ''Protecteur'' arrives home|date=25 November 2002|work=[[The Guelph Mercury]]|publisher=Metroland Media Group|page=B12|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref> Operation Apollo was the largest Canadian deployment since the [[Canada in the Korean War|Korean War]].<ref name="Conrad2011">{{cite book|last=Conrad|first=LCol. John|title=Scarce Heard Amid the Guns: An Inside Look at Canadian Peacekeeping|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LxmxBkiubkwC&pg=PA215|accessdate=1 December 2013|date=15 September 2011|publisher=Dundurn Press|isbn=978-1-4597-0096-3|page=215}}</ref> ''Protecteur'' participated in RIMPAC again in 2004, along with the {{HMCS|Algonquin|DDG 283|2}} and {{HMCS|Regina|FFH 334|2}}.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cpf.navy.mil/RIMPAC2004/news_page/Algoquin_story/algoquin_story.htm|archivedate=10 March 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050310191019/http://www.cpf.navy.mil/RIMPAC2004/news_page/Algoquin_story/algoquin_story.htm|title=''Algonquin'' Embarks Upon RIMPAC|last=Rozenberg|first=SLt. Kelly|publisher=[[United States Navy]]|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref>
[[File:USNS Sioux (T-ATF-171) towing HMCS Protecteur (AOR 509) in 2014.JPG|thumb|left|USNS ''Sioux'' towing ''Protecteur'' in March 2014]]
On 19 September 2011, ''Protecteur'' departed from CFB Esquimalt for a two month deployment off southern California as part of the {{USS|Abraham Lincoln|CVN 72|6}} [[Carrier Strike Group Nine|carrier strike group]]. ''Protecteur'' joined the destroyer ''Algonquin'' and the frigate {{HMCS|Ottawa|FFH 341|2}} in [[Fleet Week]] activities in [[San Diego|San Diego, California]], between 26 and 30 September 2011.<ref name="fleet week">{{cite news|url=http://www.vicnews.com/news/129996593.html|title=CFB Esquimalt supply ship heading south for warfare training|last=McCracken|first=E|date=16 September 2011|work=[[Victoria News]]|publisher=[[Black Press]]|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref> On 30 August 2013, the ship was involved in a collision with ''Algonquin'' during towing exercises. There were no injuries to personnel, although ''Protecteur'' sustained damage to her bow.<ref>{{cite news |title=2 Canadian warships collide en route to Hawaii |url= http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/2-canadian-warships-collide-en-route-to-hawaii-1.1309679 |work=CBC News |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |agency=The Canadian Press |date=31 August 2013 |accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref> The damage was repaired in time for ''Protecteur'' to participate in a Task Group Exercise with the United States Navy in mid-October 2013.<ref>{{cite press release|title=U.S. and Canadian Navies Complete Task Group Exercise|publisher=[[United States Navy]]|date=15 October 2013|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=77092|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref>
On 20 February 2014, ''Protecteur'' suffered an engine room fire and breakdown {{convert|340|nmi}} northeast of [[Naval Station Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]], [[Hawaii]]. She was moving at limited speeds and the [[United States Navy]] {{sclass-|Arleigh Burke|destroyer|1}} {{USS|Michael Murphy|DDG-112|2}}, {{sclass-|Ticonderoga|cruiser|1}} {{USS|Chosin|CG-65|2}}, and the [[Military Sealift Command]]-operated {{sclass-|Powhatan|fleet ocean tug|1}} {{USNS|Sioux|T-ATF-171|2}} were dispatched to assist. ''Chosin'' attempted to tow ''Protecteur'', but the towing line broke.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!-- staff writer --> |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/line-towing-fire-damaged-hmcs-protecteur-to-hawaii-breaks-1.2555354 |title=Line towing fire-damaged HMCS ''Protecteur'' to Hawaii breaks |date=2 March 2014 |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |work=CBC News |access-date=3 March 2014}}</ref> About 20 members of the ship's crew were injured as a result of the fire,<ref>{{cite news |title=HMCS ''Protecteur'' towed into Pearl Harbor |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/hmcs-protecteur-towed-into-pearl-harbor-1.2562634 |accessdate=7 March 2014 |work=CBC News |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |date=6 March 2014}}</ref> and her engines were badly damaged.<ref>{{cite news |last=<!-- staff writer -->|title=HMCS ''Protecteur'' arrives safely, but suffers devastating damage |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/hmcs-protecteur-arrives-safely-but-suffers-devastating-damage-1.1717333 |accessdate=7 March 2014 |work=CTV News |publisher=[[Bell Media]] |date=6 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |last=Hubenthal |first=Christopher |author2=U.S. 3rd Fleet Public Affairs |location=Joint Base Pearl Harbor Hickam |agency=Navy News Service |title=HMCS ''Protecteur'', Crew Arrive Safely to Pearl Harbor |url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=79524 |date=7 March 2014 |accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref> After a preliminary assessment, it was decided that the vessel could not be repaired in Pearl Harbor.<ref>{{cite news |last=<!-- staff writer --> |title=HMCS ''Protecteur'' too badly damaged to sail home on her own |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/hmcs-protecteur-too-badly-damaged-to-sail-home-on-her-own-1.2573437 |work=CBC News |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |date=14 May 2014 |access-date=30 April 2015}}</ref> On 16 May ''Protecteur'' left Pearl Harbor under tow from the United States Military Sealift Command-operated {{sclass-|Safeguard|rescue and salvage ship|0}} [[rescue and salvage ship]] {{USNS|Salvor|T-ARS-52|2}} for an expected three week journey to her home port of CFB Esquimalt.<ref name="cbc.ca">{{cite news |last=<!-- staff writer --> |title=HMCS ''Protecteur'' heading home under tow from U.S. navy tug |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/hmcs-protecteur-heading-home-under-tow-from-u-s-navy-tug-1.2645465 |work=CBC News |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |date=16 March 2014 |access-date=30 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shipspotting.com/gallery/photo.php?lid=2034620 |website=Shipspotting.com Photo Gallery |title=USNS ''Salvor'' (T-ARS 52) - IMO 8434374 |date=16 May 2014 |access-date=30 April 2015}}</ref> ''Protecteur'' was delivered to Esquimalt on 31 May 2014.<ref>{{cite news |last=Petrescu |first=Sarah |title=Three months after fire, HMCS ''Protecteur'' back in Esquimalt |url=http://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/three-months-after-fire-hmcs-protecteur-back-in-esquimalt-1.1098293 |newspaper=Times Colonist |location=Victoria, BC |date=30 May 2014 |access-date=30 April 2015}}</ref>
==Retirement and replacement== ''Protecteur'' was decommissioned at a farewell ceremony on 14 May 2015.<ref name=CTV-2015-05-14/> Plans for replacing ''Protecteur'' and her sister ship, ''Preserver'', were first brought up in 2004.<ref>{{cite journal |date=23 March 2009 |title=SeaWaves Today in History |publisher=Shirlaw News Group |oclc=77076813 |issn=1710-6966 |url=http://www.seawaves.com/newsletters/TDIH/march/23Mar.txt |accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> Lack of spare parts for the ship's boiler and the fact that she is a single-skinned tanker were the main driving points to replacing ''Protecteur'' and ''Preserver''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/doc/355936852.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+25%2C+2008&author=Brewster%2C+Murray&pub=The+Guelph+Mercury&edition=&startpage=&desc=Tories+scuttle+replacement+plan+for+obsolete+navy+supply+ships |title=Tories scuttle replacement plan for obsolete navy supply ships |last=Brewster |first=Murray |date=25 August 2008 |work=The Guelph Mercury |publisher=Metroland Media Group |page=A6|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="monohull">{{cite news |subscription=yes|via=ProQuest|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/738297676?accountid=3357 |title=Navy ships risk being banned from ports |last=Curry |first=Bill |last2=Clark |first2=Campbell |date=6 August 2010 |work=The Globe and Mail |page=A7 |accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref>
It had been planned that the ship would have continued to operate until 2015;<ref name="slippingdates">{{cite news|title=Schedule conflict to cost taxpayers $55 million |last=Berthiaume |first=Lee |date=12 October 2013 |work=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |publisher=[[Postmedia Network]]}}</ref> however, the [[Joint Support Ship Project]] would not have been completed until two years later,<ref name="twoyear wait">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/arctic-icebreaker-delayed-as-tories-prioritize-supply-ships-1.1991522 |title=Arctic icebreaker delayed as Tories prioritize supply ships |work=CBC News |date=11 October 2013 |publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada |accessdate=29 November 2013 |agency=The Canadian Press}}</ref> leaving a gap in the ability of the RCN to refuel and resupply her own ships while deployed. Following extensive damage as a result of a fire in February 2014, ''Protecteur''{{'}}s decommissioning was brought forward as repairs would have been "...too expensive for the navy to consider" given that she was due to be retired in 2017.<ref name="cbc.ca"/>
On 19 September 2014, Vice-Admiral [[Mark Norman (RCN officer)|Mark Norman]] announced the retirement of ''Protecteur'', along with her sister ship {{HMCS|Preserver|AOR 510|6}} and the ''Iroquois''-class destroyers {{HMCS|Iroquois|DDG 280|6}} and {{HMCS|Algonquin|DDG 283|6}}. The Royal Canadian Navy is looking at other options to fill the supply gap until the arrival of the two {{sclass-|Queenston|auxiliary vessel|1}}s in 2019 at the earliest.<ref name=ctva>{{cite news |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/navy-sending-four-cold-war-era-ships-into-retirement-1.2014607 |title=Navy sending four Cold War era ships into retirement |agency=[[The Canadian Press]] |work=CTV News |publisher=Bell Media |date=19 September 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014}}</ref> ''Protecteur'', along with ''Algonquin'', was sold for [[Ship breaking|scrapping]] on 27 November 2015 to R.J. MacIsaac Ltd. of [[Antigonish]], Nova Scotia. They will be towed to Nova Scotia where the work will be done<ref name=dedyna1>{{cite news |url=http://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/two-cfb-esquimalt-ships-going-on-long-journey-to-be-demolished-1.2150742 |title=Two CFB Esquimalt ships going on long journey to be demolished |work=Times Colonist |last=Dedyna |first=Katherine |date=14 January 2016 |accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> at [[Liverpool, Nova Scotia|Liverpool]].<ref name=ward1/>
In October 2015, {{MS|Asterix}}, a container ship, was acquired by Davie Shipyards to be converted into an auxiliary vessel, to be leased to the RCN as a temporary bridge between the ''Protecteur'' class until the ''Queenston'' class becomes available. However, no contract has yet been signed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/defence-watch/canadas-navy-isnt-interested-in-a-deal-for-second-commercial-fuel-tanker-to-supply-warships |title=Canada’s navy isn’t interested in a deal for second commercial fuel tanker to supply warships |work=Ottawa Citizen |last=Pugliese |first=David |date=15 October 2015 |accessdate=12 November 2015}}</ref>
